title: Shades of Red Color: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: A collection of over 100 red color shades with accurate hex codes, symbolic meanings, and practical uses for web design, branding, interiors, and creative work.
content:
Shades of red cover a wide emotional and visual spectrum. They move from deep, moody tones like Burgundy, Maroon, and Oxblood to high-impact shades such as Scarlet, Crimson, Ruby, and Vermilion. Red (#FF0000) is one of the most expressive colors. Color psychology research shows it signals passion, urgency, warmth, power, and intensity. Consequently, it dominates branding, fashion, interiors, and digital design. Some reds feel bold and aggressive. Others seem romantic and refined. Meanwhile, a few lean earthy and grounded. Popular shades each bring a distinct personality. Therefore, red is one of the most versatile colors.

Deep and Dark Reds

These shades feel rich, dramatic, and luxurious. They often carry purple or brown undertones. Accordingly, they work well for premium branding, wine labels, and elegant interiors.
Examples include Burgundy, Maroon, Oxblood, Garnet, Sangria, Merlot, Wine Red, Mahogany, and Red Velvet.

Bright and Vibrant Reds

These are high-energy reds that demand attention. Typically, they are the shades people imagine for pure red. They symbolize excitement, love, urgency, and confidence.
Examples include Scarlet, Crimson, Ruby, Cherry Red, Fire Engine Red, Lipstick Red, Candy Apple Red, Rosso Corsa, and Signal Red.

Warm and Orange Reds

These reds lean toward orange and feel fiery, spicy, and energetic. Studies link warm colors to increased arousal. Thus, they work well for food brands, sports visuals, and action-focused designs.
Examples include Vermilion, Tomato Red, Coral Red, Chili Pepper, Flame Red, Cayenne, Grenadine, Poppy Red, and Inferno Red.

Earthy and Subdued Reds

These are muted reds inspired by soil, clay, and natural pigments. They feel stable, grounded, and organic. So, they are popular in architecture, fashion, and lifestyle brands.
Examples include Brick Red, Rust Red, Redwood, Oxide Red, Henna, Fired Clay, Tuscany Red, Sedona Red, and Burnt Red.

Soft and Pinkish Reds

These are gentler reds that blend romance and warmth. They are not overpowering. Hence, they work well for beauty, wellness, and modern minimalist designs.
Examples include Rose Red, Blush Red, Salmon, Cerise, Flamingo Red, Berry Red, and Cupid Red.

Scarlet

Scarlet (#FF2400) is a brilliantly intense red with a slight orange undertone. Historically, it was a symbol of both status and sin, often associated with cardinals’ robes and military uniforms. Furthermore, it is linked to courage, passion, and warning. Consequently, Scarlet is widely used in flags, ceremonial wear, and safety applications. It commands immediate visual attention.

  • HEX #FF2400
  • RGB 255, 36, 0
  • CMYK 0, 86, 100, 0

Crimson

Crimson (#DC143C) is a rich, deep red with a strong blue undertone. Its name derives from the “kermes” insect used to produce the dye in antiquity, making it a historically prestigious and costly pigment. Moreover, it is traditionally linked to power, nobility, and, in some contexts, martyrdom. As a result, Crimson is frequently found in academic regalia, heraldry, and luxury branding where it conveys depth and sophistication.

  • HEX #DC143C
  • RGB 220, 20, 60
  • CMYK 0, 91, 73, 14

Ruby

Ruby (#E0115F) is a vivid, purplish-red color named after the precious gemstone. This color conveys a sense of luxury, passion, and vitality, directly mirroring the gem’s associations. It is often seen in jewelry design, fashion accessories, and high-end cosmetics. Ultimately, Ruby evokes a feeling of dramatic elegance and intense love.

  • HEX #E0115F
  • RGB 224, 17, 95
  • CMYK 0, 92, 58, 12

Burgundy

Burgundy (#800020) is a very dark red with strong purple or brown undertones, named after the Burgundy wine region of France. It is synonymous with sophistication, maturity, and opulence. Therefore, Burgundy is a staple in formal attire, luxury product packaging, and interior design. This color projects an aura of understated wealth and refined taste.

  • HEX #800020
  • RGB 128, 0, 32
  • CMYK 0, 100, 75, 50

Cherry Red

Cherry Red (#DE3163) is a bright, saturated red reminiscent of ripe cherries. It strikes a balance between playful vibrancy and classic appeal, often associated with youthful energy, sweetness, and boldness. Consequently, it is popular in vintage graphics, candy packaging, and playful fashion items. This shade is cheerful and eye-catching without being overly aggressive.

  • HEX #DE3163
  • RGB 222, 49, 99
  • CMYK 0, 78, 55, 13

Fire Engine Red

Fire Engine Red (#CE2029) is an intensely vivid, slightly orange-tinted red designed for maximum visibility. It is the universal symbol for emergency services and immediate danger. Furthermore, this color is psychologically proven to increase heart rate and urgency. Consequently, it is used not only for fire trucks but also for critical warning signs, stop signals, and high-impact marketing where attention is non-negotiable.

  • HEX #CE2029
  • RGB 206, 32, 41
  • CMYK 0, 84, 80, 19

Blood Red

Blood Red (#660000) is a very dark, desaturated red that evokes its namesake. Historically, it has been associated with life, sacrifice, and mortality across many cultures. This color carries a solemn, primal, and sometimes macabre weight. Therefore, it is effectively used in horror genres, historical reenactments, and symbolism related to vitality and loss.

  • HEX #660000
  • RGB 102, 0, 0
  • CMYK 0, 100, 100, 60

Carmine

Carmine (#960018) is a deep, pure red with a minor purple influence, derived from the cochineal insect. For centuries, it was a highly prized and vibrant dye used in textiles and art. Moreover, it represents wealth, vibrancy, and natural pigment. Today, it is used in food coloring, artistic paints, and rich fabric dyes. This color offers a historically saturated and bold presence.

  • HEX #960018
  • RGB 150, 0, 24
  • CMYK 0, 100, 84, 41

Vermilion

Vermilion (#E34234) is a brilliant reddish-orange, originally made from powdered mineral cinnabar. It has been a prominent pigment in Asian art and Renaissance paintings. Additionally, it symbolizes joy, prosperity, and religious sanctity in various Eastern cultures. Thus, Vermilion is iconic in traditional lacquerware, ceremonial gates, and classic masterpieces. It is a warm, luminous, and historically significant hue.

  • HEX #E34234
  • RGB 227, 66, 52
  • CMYK 0, 71, 77, 11

Cardinal

Cardinal (#C41E3A) is a vivid, bluish-red named after the robes of Catholic cardinals. It directly signifies ecclesiastical authority, ceremony, and confidence. This color stands out with a regal yet vibrant presence. Consequently, it is used in sports team uniforms, academic insignia, and designs requiring a dignified pop of color. Cardinal is both energetic and formal.

  • HEX #C41E3A
  • RGB 196, 30, 58
  • CMYK 0, 85, 70, 23

Mahogany

Mahogany (#C04000) is a dark, reddish-brown color named after the prized tropical hardwood. It evokes a sense of richness, durability, and classic craftsmanship. Furthermore, this color is associated with elegance, tradition, and grounded stability. Consequently, Mahogany is a dominant choice for fine furniture, leather goods, and interior design accents. It provides a warm, sophisticated, and timeless foundation.

  • HEX #C04000
  • RGB 192, 64, 0
  • CMYK 0, 67, 100, 25

Rose Red

Rose Red (#C21E56) is a medium, purplish-pink red reminiscent of a deep red rose. It is universally linked to romance, gratitude, and beauty. This shade carries a softer, more feminine connotation than primary red. Therefore, Rose Red is prevalent in floral design, Valentine’s branding, and cosmetics. It expresses love and appreciation in a gentle yet definite way.

  • HEX #C21E56
  • RGB 194, 30, 86
  • CMYK 0, 85, 56, 24

Brick Red

Brick Red (#CB4154) is a muted, medium-dark red with clear brown and orange tones, like fired clay. It signifies warmth, resilience, and rustic simplicity. This color feels earthy, sturdy, and comforting. As a result, Brick Red is ideal for home exterior paints, autumn-themed designs, and casual apparel. It creates an approachable and grounded aesthetic.

  • HEX #CB4154
  • RGB 203, 65, 84
  • CMYK 0, 68, 59, 20

Tomato Red

Tomato Red (#FF6347) is a bold, warm red with a distinct orange influence, named after the ripe vegetable. It exudes health, vibrancy, and approachable energy. Moreover, this color is friendly, appetizing, and full of life. Consequently, Tomato Red is frequently used in food packaging, kitchenware design, and playful graphics. It is a juicy and inviting shade.

  • HEX #FF6347
  • RGB 255, 99, 71
  • CMYK 0, 61, 72, 0

Cedar Chest

Cedar Chest (#C95A49) is a muted, medium red-brown inspired by the color of finished cedar wood. It evokes feelings of heritage, warmth, and security. This color is reminiscent of heirlooms, cozy interiors, and natural wood grain. Therefore, it is commonly used in craftsmanship branding, rustic decor, and autumn fashion. Cedar Chest offers a reassuring and nostalgic feel.

  • HEX #C95A49
  • RGB 201, 90, 73
  • CMYK 0, 55, 64, 21

Rust Red

Rust Red (#B7410E) is a deep, reddish-brown that mimics the color of iron oxide. It inherently suggests age, weathering, and organic decay. Furthermore, this color is associated with autumn, industrial heritage, and a vintage aesthetic. Consequently, Rust Red is popular in industrial design, rustic wedding themes, and fall palettes. It provides a textured, earthy, and authentic look.

  • HEX #B7410E
  • RGB 183, 65, 14
  • CMYK 0, 64, 92, 28

Persian Red

Persian Red (#C81D11) is a deep, rich red with historical origins in Persian carpets and art. It symbolizes wealth, passion, and artistic grandeur. This color carries an exotic and luxurious connotation. Therefore, Persian Red is often used in oriental rug design, traditional motifs, and opulent interiors. It evokes a sense of historical depth and cultured richness.

  • HEX #C81D11
  • RGB 200, 29, 17
  • CMYK 0, 85, 92, 22

Sangria

Sangria (#92000A) is a very dark, muted red, named after the Spanish wine punch. It embodies sophistication, richness, and social warmth. This color is reminiscent of aged wine, dusk, and intimate gatherings. As a result, Sangria is effective for elegant dining spaces, mature branding, and cold-weather fashion. It feels deep, indulgent, and slightly mysterious.

  • HEX #92000A
  • RGB 146, 0, 10
  • CMYK 0, 100, 93, 43

Cerise

Cerise (#DE3163) is a vivid, deep pinkish-red, similar to a ripe cherry. Its name is the French word for “cherry”. This shade is playful, flirtatious, and highly energetic. Consequently, Cerise is a staple in fashion, particularly in evening wear, and vibrant graphic design. It makes a bold, modern, and cheerful statement.

  • HEX #DE3163
  • RGB 222, 49, 99
  • CMYK 0, 78, 55, 13

Candy Apple Red

Candy Apple Red (#FF0800) is a bright, glossy, high-impact red with a strong orange undertone, mimicking the confection. It represents speed, shine, and classic Americana. Moreover, it is inextricably linked to hot rods, custom automotive finishes, and 1950s nostalgia. Therefore, this color is iconic in automotive culture, retro branding, and any design seeking a sleek, attention-grabbing pop.

  • HEX #FF0800
  • RGB 255, 8, 0
  • CMYK 0, 97, 100, 0

Coral Red

Coral Red (#FF4040) is a warm, luminous blend of pink, orange, and red, inspired by sea coral. It evokes feelings of warmth, vibrancy, and tropical energy. This shade is more playful and approachable than a true red. Consequently, Coral Red is widely used in summer fashion, beach-themed designs, and youthful branding. It is inviting, cheerful, and full of life.

  • HEX #FF4040
  • RGB 255, 64, 64
  • CMYK 0, 75, 75, 0

Poppy Red

Poppy Red (#DC343B) is a bright, saturated red with a slight floral softness, named after the red poppy flower. It is a symbol of remembrance, sacrifice, and vibrant life. Furthermore, this color carries emotional weight and natural beauty. Therefore, Poppy Red is used in memorial imagery, floral patterns, and impactful artistic expressions. It is both poignant and strikingly beautiful.

  • HEX #DC343B
  • RGB 220, 52, 59
  • CMYK 0, 76, 73, 14

Raspberry Red

Raspberry Red (#E30B5D) is a rich, deep pinkish-red that mirrors the color of ripe raspberries. It embodies indulgence, sweetness, and a bold, modern flair. This color is energetic yet sophisticated. As a result, Raspberry Red is popular in contemporary fashion, cosmetics, and gourmet food packaging. It feels luscious, dynamic, and slightly daring.

  • HEX #E30B5D
  • RGB 227, 11, 93
  • CMYK 0, 95, 59, 11

Merlot

Merlot (#722F37) is a very dark, muted red with strong brown and purple notes, named after the wine. It signifies refinement, depth, and understated luxury. This color is classic, mature, and calming. Consequently, Merlot is a favorite in fine dining aesthetics, luxury leather goods, and cozy, elegant interiors. It exudes confidence and timeless taste.

  • HEX #722F37
  • RGB 114, 47, 55
  • CMYK 0, 59, 52, 55

Wine Red

Wine Red (#5E2129) is a deep, desaturated red, darker than Merlot, directly evoking red wine. It represents sophistication, richness, and a hint of mystery. This shade is associated with tradition, elegance, and the passage of time. Therefore, Wine Red is used in formal event branding, classic automotive interiors, and deep academic regalia. It is a profound and authoritative color.

  • HEX #5E2129
  • RGB 94, 33, 41
  • CMYK 0, 65, 56, 63

Maroon

Maroon (#800000) is a very dark brownish-red, often associated with formal education and military uniforms. It symbolizes discipline, ambition, and controlled strength. This color is more conservative and serious than brighter reds. Consequently, Maroon is a staple in university branding, blazers, and designs requiring a dignified, powerful presence. It projects tradition and authority.

  • HEX #800000
  • RGB 128, 0, 0
  • CMYK 0, 100, 100, 50

Sienna Red

Sienna Red (#9C5145) is an earthy, reddish-brown color derived from the natural clay pigment sienna. It evokes a sense of warmth, earthiness, and organic artistry. Historically, it has been a fundamental pigment in painting since the Renaissance. Therefore, Sienna Red is prevalent in landscape art, rustic design, and terracotta pottery. It feels natural, rustic, and timeless.

  • HEX #9C5145
  • RGB 156, 81, 69
  • CMYK 0, 48, 56, 39

Henna

Henna (#B3675D) is a muted, reddish-brown color inspired by the natural dye used for body art. It is deeply connected to celebration, tradition, and cultural beauty rituals. This color signifies joy, good fortune, and temporary adornment. Consequently, Henna is used in bohemian designs, wedding motifs, and artisanal crafts. It carries a warm, artistic, and spiritual vibe.

  • HEX #B3675D
  • RGB 179, 103, 93
  • CMYK 0, 42, 48, 30

Garnet

Garnet (#733635) is a dark, slightly purple-toned red, named after the semi-precious stone. It symbolizes protection, commitment, and deep-rooted passion. This color is perceived as solid, valuable, and enduring. As a result, Garnet is used in fine jewelry, January birthstone themes, and rich, dramatic interiors. It feels luxurious, steadfast, and intense.

  • HEX #733635
  • RGB 115, 54, 53
  • CMYK 0, 53, 54, 55

Cranberry

Cranberry (#9F000F) is a deep, vibrant red with a hint of blue, reminiscent of the tart berry. It evokes boldness, festivity, and a tangy zest. This color is strongly associated with holiday seasons and hearty cuisine. Therefore, Cranberry is popular in seasonal decor, festive tableware, and winter fashion accents. It is rich, lively, and warmly inviting.

  • HEX #9F000F
  • RGB 159, 0, 15
  • CMYK 0, 100, 91, 38

Red Ochre

Red Ochre (#913831) is an earthy, reddish-brown pigment made from natural clay containing iron oxide. It is one of the oldest colors used by humans, found in prehistoric cave paintings. This color represents earth, primal energy, and survival. Consequently, Red Ochre is used in historical art reproductions, primitive-style decor, and natural clay finishes. It feels ancient, organic, and grounded.

  • HEX #913831
  • RGB 145, 56, 49
  • CMYK 0, 61, 66, 43

Indian Red

Indian Red (#CD5C5C) is a medium, desaturated red with a subtle earthy tone. Its name originates from a natural red iron oxide pigment originally sourced from India. This color conveys a sense of warmth, earthiness, and natural pigment. Therefore, Indian Red is common in Southwestern design, artistic palettes, and terracotta materials. It is a muted, versatile, and comforting shade.

  • HEX #CD5C5C
  • RGB 205, 92, 92
  • CMYK 0, 55, 55, 20

Rustic Red

Rustic Red (#A34739) is a warm, muted red-brown that evokes weathered wood and dried clay. It embodies simplicity, the outdoors, and handcrafted authenticity. This color feels lived-in, cozy, and unpretentious. As a result, Rustic Red is ideal for farmhouse decor, artisanal branding, and autumn landscapes. It creates an approachable and natural atmosphere.

  • HEX #A34739
  • RGB 163, 71, 57
  • CMYK 0, 56, 65, 36

Brick Dust

Brick Dust (#BC4A3A) is a soft, muted reddish-orange, resembling powdered clay. It suggests warmth, subtlety, and a sun-baked quality. This color is less intense than true brick, offering a gentle, weathered look. Consequently, Brick Dust is used in vintage signage, desert-themed design, and muted artistic backgrounds. It provides a soft, nostalgic, and earthy tone.

  • HEX #BC4A3A
  • RGB 188, 74, 58
  • CMYK 0, 61, 69, 26

Redwood

Redwood (#A45A52) is a medium, grayish-reddish-brown inspired by the heartwood of the redwood tree. It signifies strength, longevity, and natural grandeur. This color is calming, majestic, and organic. Therefore, Redwood is prevalent in natural wood finishes, outdoor branding, and designs aiming for a serene, earthy feel. It evokes stability and natural beauty.

  • HEX #A45A52
  • RGB 164, 90, 82
  • CMYK 0, 45, 50, 36

Sedona Red

Sedona Red (#B51B25) is a warm, earthy red inspired by the iconic rock formations of Sedona, Arizona. It embodies the raw beauty, spiritual energy, and warmth of the desert. This color feels both powerful and grounding. Consequently, Sedona Red is used in Southwestern art, spa and wellness branding, and landscape photography themes. It evokes a sense of natural wonder and serene majesty.

  • HEX #B51B25
  • RGB 181, 27, 37
  • CMYK 0, 85, 80, 29

Alizarin Crimson

Alizarin Crimson (#E32636) is a deep, cool, slightly pinkish red with a historical origin as a madder lake pigment. It was a crucial, transparent red for artists for centuries. This color is prized for its richness, transparency, and mixing capabilities in painting. Therefore, Alizarin Crimson remains a staple on fine artists’ palettes for glazing and creating deep shadows. It is a historic, vibrant, and essential artistic hue.

  • HEX #E32636
  • RGB 227, 38, 54
  • CMYK 0, 83, 76, 11

Candy Pinkish Red

Candy Pinkish Red (#F64A8A) is a bright, high-energy blend of pink and red, reminiscent of sugary confections. It exudes playfulness, sweetness, and youthful exuberance. This color is unapologetically fun and trendy. As a result, it is frequently seen in contemporary fashion, candy packaging, and playful digital graphics. It makes a bold, cheerful, and modern statement.

  • HEX #F64A8A
  • RGB 246, 74, 138
  • CMYK 0, 70, 44, 4

Blush Red

Blush Red (#DE5D83) is a soft, muted pinkish-red, like a gentle flush on the cheeks. It conveys delicacy, romance, and understated health. This shade is softer and more demure than bolder reds. Consequently, Blush Red is popular in cosmetics, wedding color palettes, and intimate lingerie design. It offers a subtle, feminine, and warm touch.

  • HEX #DE5D83
  • RGB 222, 93, 131
  • CMYK 0, 58, 41, 13

Salsa Red

Salsa Red (#FD5308) is a vibrant, fiery orange-red, named after the spicy condiment. It suggests heat, zest, and lively energy. This color is exciting, appetizing, and full of motion. Therefore, Salsa Red is effective in food branding, fitness industry graphics, and festive cultural designs. It is a spicy, energetic, and attention-grabbing shade.

  • HEX #FD5308
  • RGB 253, 83, 8
  • CMYK 0, 67, 97, 1

Pale Red

Pale Red (#F4A5A5) is a very light, desaturated pinkish-red with high white content. It evokes softness, innocence, and gentle warmth. This color is delicate, calming, and non-threatening. Consequently, Pale Red is used in nursery decor, vintage aesthetic designs, and as a subtle background tint. It provides a quiet, romantic, and airy feeling.

  • HEX #F4A5A5
  • RGB 244, 165, 165
  • CMYK 0, 32, 32, 4

Bright Red

Bright Red (#EE4B2B) is a high-intensity, pure red with a slight orange tilt, optimized for maximum visibility. It is the archetypal color for urgency, excitement, and bold statements. This shade commands immediate attention and action. Therefore, Bright Red is fundamental in sale signage, warning labels, and iconic brand logos. It is unmissable and powerfully stimulating.

  • HEX #EE4B2B
  • RGB 238, 75, 43
  • CMYK 0, 68, 82, 7

Intense Red

Intense Red (#C40233) is a deep, saturated red that is vibrant yet slightly darkened. It embodies passion, drama, and controlled power. This color is more sophisticated and less childish than a primary bright red. As a result, Intense Red is used in performance car finishes, dramatic fashion statements, and luxury branding. It feels dynamic, confident, and luxurious.

  • HEX #C40233
  • RGB 196, 2, 51
  • CMYK 0, 99, 74, 23

Deep Red

Deep Red (#850101) is a very dark red, close to black, retaining a clear red undertone. It signifies elegance, power, and mystery. This color is somber, rich, and formal. Consequently, Deep Red is ideal for evening gowns, luxurious velvet textures, and moody interior design accents. It creates an atmosphere of depth and refined drama.

  • HEX #850101
  • RGB 133, 1, 1
  • CMYK 0, 99, 99, 48

Dark Red

Dark Red (#8B0000) is a standard dark pure red, slightly lighter than deep red. It represents strength, will, and determined passion. This color is classic, authoritative, and somewhat traditional. Therefore, Dark Red is common in corporate branding where trust is key, classic automotive paints, and formal stationery. It is a solid, reliable, and powerful shade.

  • HEX #8B0000
  • RGB 139, 0, 0
  • CMYK 0, 100, 100, 45

True Red

True Red (#BF0D0D) is a saturated, medium red that represents the purest, most balanced ideal of red without clear orange or blue bias. It is the psychological primary red associated with love, danger, and importance. This color is direct, honest, and commanding. Consequently, True Red is used in national flags, critical alerts, and branding that requires unambiguous impact. It is the quintessential red.

  • HEX #BF0D0D
  • RGB 191, 13, 13
  • CMYK 0, 93, 93, 25

Neon Red

Neon Red (#FF073A) is an extremely bright, fluorescent red with a pinkish undertone, mimicking gas-discharge tube lighting. It embodies extreme energy, nightlife, and futuristic vibrancy. This color is loud, artificial, and impossible to ignore. Therefore, Neon Red is iconic in club graphics, 80s retro design, and high-visibility athletic wear. It is electric and hyper-modern.

  • HEX #FF073A
  • RGB 255, 7, 58
  • CMYK 0, 97, 77, 0

Flame Red

Flame Red (#CF352E) is a bright, warm red-orange that captures the color of a burning fire. It symbolizes heat, transformation, and primal energy. This color is dynamic, dangerous, and alluring. As a result, Flame Red is used in sports team logos, fire-related safety graphics, and designs meant to convey speed and power. It is hot, lively, and intense.

  • HEX #CF352E
  • RGB 207, 53, 46
  • CMYK 0, 74, 78, 19

Signal Red

Signal Red (#A91F1F) is a defined, medium red standardized for maximum visibility and recognition in technical and safety contexts. It is engineered to be clearly distinguishable under various lighting conditions. Consequently, Signal Red is mandated for traffic stop signs, emergency buttons, and aviation navigation lights. It is a functional, unambiguous, and life-critical color.

  • HEX #A91F1F
  • RGB 169, 31, 31
  • CMYK 0, 82, 82, 34

Torch Red

Torch Red (#F51720) is a vibrant, pure red with exceptional brightness, named for its resemblance to a flame’s core. It represents celebrations, guidance, and intense passion. This color is festive, leading, and bold. Therefore, Torch Red is prominent in festival decorations, award ribbons, and branding that aims to lead and inspire. It is a beacon of vivid energy.

  • HEX #F51720
  • RGB 245, 23, 32
  • CMYK 0, 91, 87, 4

Pop Red

Pop Red (#EA3C53) is a bright, cheerful red with a noticeable pink influence, often associated with pop art and modern culture. It embodies fun, youthfulness, and commercial appeal. This color is energetic, trendy, and approachable. Consequently, Pop Red is widely used in contemporary advertising, toy design, and social media graphics. It is designed to be eye-catching and delightfully mainstream.

  • HEX #EA3C53
  • RGB 234, 60, 83
  • CMYK 0, 74, 65, 8

Cardinal Red

Cardinal Red (#9E1E32) is a deep, slightly bluish red, explicitly referencing the bird and the ecclesiastical official. It symbolizes vitality, focus, and traditional authority. This color is crisp, distinctive, and formal. Therefore, Cardinal Red is a common color for prestigious universities, sports teams, and official regalia. It projects confidence and institutional pride.

  • HEX #9E1E32
  • RGB 158, 30, 50
  • CMYK 0, 81, 68, 38

Venetian Red

Venetian Red (#C80815) is a warm, earthy red pigment historically made from natural clay. It was a staple in Renaissance painting and fresco work. This color conveys warmth, antiquity, and artistic heritage. Consequently, Venetian Red is favored in historical restoration, fine art, and Mediterranean-style architecture. It feels classic, earthy, and culturally rich.

  • HEX #C80815
  • RGB 200, 8, 21
  • CMYK 0, 96, 90, 22

Rust Red Brown

Rust Red Brown (#8B3103) is a dark, muted brown with a dominant red oxide character. It strongly suggests age, weathering, and industrial decay. This color is textural, organic, and nostalgic. As a result, it is used in steampunk design, vintage machinery aesthetics, and autumn harvest themes. It creates a weathered, authentic, and rustic impression.

  • HEX #8B3103
  • RGB 139, 49, 3
  • CMYK 0, 65, 98, 45

Carmine Red

Carmine Red (#A2231D) is a deep, pure red, specifically referencing the carmine pigment derived from cochineal insects. It is a historically rich and colorfast dye.
